headline: Psalm 7
description: At the water’s edge, a walk of sorrow becomes a baptismal crossing. The ache is named holy; the crossing is chosen; love is promised. A River Moon psalm.
author: Aleksandr Agnitio
whyItMatters: Marks a turn from private ache to chosen movement—sorrow flowing outward into compassion. It articulates a theology of effortful grace: the path to Him is harder, yet love meets you on the far bank.

motifMap.meaning: Repetition and return; the cycle of trial
Threshold; baptismal crossing; purification and courage
Sanctified suffering; pain as proof of a living heart
Divine ability contrasted with human responsibility

articleExcerpt: He said the ache was holy—that the pain of the wound proved the goodness of my heart. He could walk on water, but the path to him is harder. So I crossed.

sourceFragments.quote: Walking an old path, the same footprints fit my feet,
He said the ache was holy—
He could walk on water. He could take it away. But the path to him is harder.
So I crossed. I dunked myself in his water.

sourceFragments.note: Final assurance; identity sealed in love

associatedMedia.description: Classical painting of Christ with a penitent at a riverbank (illustration used in the post).
